Award.AwardTitle: CADathlon 2010: International Graduate Student Progg. Contest in EDA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are requested to provide limted support to US based students to participate in CADathlon contest.

CADathlon is an annual graduate student programming contest held in conjunction with the ICCAD (International Conference on Computer-Aided Design) conference held annually in SanJose, California. The contest problems are chosen from the Electronic Design Automation (EDA) field and are posed by EDA experts from academia and industry. The contest is open to all graduate students pursuing their degrees in EDA.
CADathlon was started in 2002 and every year attracts 15-20 teams from universities all over the world. In the eight CADathlon contests held so far, one or more graduate student teams from 26 US and 10 foreign universities have competed. The winning and runner-up teams are awarded cash prizes. In this proposal, we seek NSF support to partially cover the expenses of 2010 CADathlon contest.

CADathlon is a vehicle to attract students who are good at problem solving to the EDA area. CADathlon directly encourages a deeper study and understanding of critical problems in the EDA/CAD field for the participants. As such, it is an invaluable resource for encouraging young researchers to pursue graduate degrees and for laying the foundations of a career in research in these areas.

ProgramReference.Text: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant is used to cover the expenses of the student participants of 2010 and 2011 ACM SIGDA CADathlon contests.

CADathlon is an annual graduate student programming contest held in conjunction with the ICCAD (International Conference on Computer-Aided Design) conference. The contest problems are chosen from the Electronic Design Automation (EDA) field and are posed by EDA experts. The contest is open to all graduate students pursuing their degrees in EDA. CADathlon was started in 2002 and every year attracts 15-20 teams from universities all over the world.

In the spirit of the long-running ACM programming contest, the CADathlon challenges students on their CAD knowledge, and their problem solving, programming, and teamwork skills. It serves as an innovative initiative to assist in the development of top students in the EDA field. The contest provides a platform for SIGDA, academia, and industry to focus attention on the best and brightest of next generation CAD professionals.

The students are given a number of problems that range in difficulty and topics. Information about the CAD areas, relevant papers, and potentially a software framework that will run on Linux is released one week before the competition. Students are allowed to work in teams of two. At the contest, students are given the problem statements and example test data, but do not have access to the judges’ test data. Solutions are judged on correctness and efficiency. The team that passes the most testcases is declared the winner. The judges are experts in EDA from both academia and industry.

During the competition students presented with six problems in the following broad areas, namely, Circuit Design & Analysis, Physical Design, Logic & High-Level Synthesis, System Design & Analysis, Functional Verification, and Bio-EDA.

The competition is open and free to all graduate students specializing in CAD currently enrolled full-time in a Ph.D. granting institution in any country. Partial or full travel grants are provided to qualifying contestants.

The following are the statistics of 2010 and 2011 CADathlon contests:

2011: 28 graduate students from 14 universities (11 US and 5 Foreign universities) participated in the 2010 contest.

2010:  34 graduate students from 17 universities (9 US and 8 Foreign universities) participated in the 2011 contest.

 


Last Modified: 04/01/2012
Modified by: Srinivas Katkoori
